newsitem.title: UK: Demutualisation of life insurers will continue - S&P.
newsitem.headline: Demutualisation of life insurers will continue - S&P.

text.p: Insurance ratings agency Standard & Poor's predicted on Tuesday that the trend towards demutualsation in the life industry would continue, but warned it did not necessarily offer the best deal for policyholders.
Speaking at a press conference in London, S&P's life insurance expert Martin Lees said the reasons for demutualisation were seen as either defensive or offensive.
Offensive reasons included the need for more capital to allow aggressive action in the market, capital which would otherwise have to be raised using debt.
"It is not that capital is king, but financial flexibility is fundamental," said Lees.
"Demutualisation could be good news for 'with profits' funds in times when solvency is under pressure," he said.

"It also frees cash for investment in information technology, and more importantly creates the ability to access further amounts of capacity whenever need, whether the company is floated or bought," he added.
However Lees stressed that this was only true if a parent company was strong and committed to the acquired company's market.
"Companies such as Aegon or Halifax would be able to offer this, but a company such as Gan has too many well-publicised problems of its own to be a reliable source of future investment," Lees said.
Lees pointed out that any price for a mutual should be set against the background of UK life insurance sales.

"Shareholders want higher returns precisely at a time when profit margins are being eroded. Sales plummeted in 1994-95, and although income is now getting back to 1993 levels, S&P believes planned profit margins are lower than they were in the mid 1980s," said Lees.

Such an environment may attract policyholders to a buyer offering a guaranteed cash windfall. Although this has never happened in the life industry, a cash goodwill element was included in last weeks 1.4 billion stg offer from Abbey National to buy Scottish Amicable.
However Lees made a plea for a longer term view.
"If a company is in a healthy position and well run, and can still achieve good profits," he said.
"Demutualisation is like taking steroids. It can be very valuable for someone in poor health, but it can have side effects. Avoid taking them unless it is absolutely necessary," he said.
